_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Castle & Cooke Cold Storage operates a refrigerated warehouse facility in Riverside, California.  As stated on the company's website, "Castle & Cooke Cold Storage is committed to being a leader in the public refrigerated warehouse industry and in our sphere of business. We promise to provide innovative, professional services of a quality that meets or exceeds the expectations of our customers, our suppliers, and our community in general. We promise to maintain our facilities to the highest standards possible.  We will offer superior service and capabilities at a reasonable and competitive price as we stay abreast of the latest technologies available in our industry and in the general business arena. Our continuing objective is to exceed the performance of other comparable companies, in part by allowing our team members at all levels to continually improve the quality and value of our service."

Castle & Cooke Cold Storage senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Castle & Cooke Cold Storage's safety and environmental policies are administered by the Safety Director.  Weekly inspections of the facility are conducted by the facility Operations Manager and Chief Engineer to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.    These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Action Plan, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Castle & Cooke Cold Storage facility is located at 2356 Fleetwood Drive in Riverside, California, approximately one mile north of Interstate 60 and approximately two miles west of Interstate 215.  The area immedia

tely surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of light commercial and industrial areas.   The facility was originally constructed in 2001. In June 2002, the facility underwent an addition of approximately 23,000 square feet, which included a dry produce cooler (1 evaporator), an addition to the north dock (2 evaporators), cold produce cooler (1 evaporator) and meat cooler (1 evaporator).    Castle & Cooke Cold Storage purchased the facility in 2009.  

The primary business of Castle & Cooke Cold Storage is to provide storage of frozen food products. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 22,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for storage of frozen food products.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 5 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 150 psig on the high side.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the CalEMA California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

Administrative Measures:
The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:

Â¿	IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie ins"
Â¿	IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System" 
Â¿	IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems"
Â¿	IIAR, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"

The Castle & Cooke Cold Storage ammoni

a refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Castle & Cooke Cold Storage facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.

Engineering Measures:
Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: an emergency shutdown switch that shuts down the compressors, pumps, and condenser (located outside by the condenser in a breakable glass box), relief valves on all pressure vessels, and continuous ventilation in the engine room to prevent ammonia explosions.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years (April 2006 - April 2011).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.
 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

Â¿	save lives;
Â¿	minimize and avoid injuries;
Â¿	protect the environment; and
Â¿	minimize property damage.

Castle & Cooke Cold Storage maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for th

e facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP regulations.  

Castle & Cooke Cold Storage personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, and the Castle & Cooke Cold Storage Operations Manager.  The Operations Manager will contact the Chief Engineer, Castle & Cooke Safety Director, and Senior Vice President of Engineering to evaluate and ascertain the significance of the leak.  If the ammonia leak is considered minor and/or minimal, the repair will be conducted by the Castle & Cooke refrigeration mechanical staff.  An outside refrigeration contractor may be contracted to further assist in the potential repairs to the equipment pertaining to the ammonia system.  For major ammonia leaks, emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.  Action is promptly taken to mitigate the leak so normal operations can resume.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Hazard Review was performed on February 28, 2001, at the Castle & Cooke Cold Storage facility. The 2001 Hazard Review study was revalidated on April 26, 2006 and again on April 25, 2011.  These studies generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Castle & Cooke Cold Storage facility located in Riverside, California.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Castle & Cooke Cold Stora

ge safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. 	Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. 	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. 	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. 	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
